content: The Act is titled the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, appropriate congressional committees, foreign air carrier, intelligence community, and secured area. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms related to airport security, including intelligence community, secured area, Security Identification Display Area, and sterile area. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms related to airport security, including intelligence community, secured area, Security Identification Display Area, and sterile area. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study on implementing enhanced security measures at various airports, including secure doors, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies. The study required under subsection (a) will include information on employee screening costs at airports that have implemented 100% screening of employees accessing secured areas. This includes costs of establishing entry and exit points and comparing costs and effectiveness of security features to the Federal Government and airports. Upon completion, the Comptroller General will assess the study. The Comptroller General will assess the study on employee screening costs at airports that have implemented 100% screening, reporting to relevant committees in Congress. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. They will also assess credentialing standards to address insider threats to aviation security. A report will be submitted to congressional committees after the assessment is completed. The Administrator will require airport operators to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area to strengthen security vetting. Applicants who do not provide their social security number may be denied access. Additionally, requirements will be issued for including a screening notice in applications for access to the area. The Administrator will require airport operators to include a notice in applications for access to a Security Identification Display Area, informing applicants that employees with access credentials may be screened at any time. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats. The Administrator will also enhance education on insider threats and mitigation strategies for aviation security personnel. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. Playbook operations for employee physical inspections will be targeted and strategic to enhance security effectiveness. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide recommendations for air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators to conduct their own employee inspections. Additionally, a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges will be established within 180 days. The Transportation Security Administration will establish a process for individuals to correct their records and have their names removed from the database if mistakenly entered. Reporting mechanisms will be determined for air carriers, foreign air carriers, and airport operators to submit data on individuals with revoked airport badges. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, foreign carriers, and airport operators. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of IT security controls within 90 days. No additional funds are authorized for these requirements. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 25, 2017. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
